summary: Gilbert Grape (Johnny Depp) is a small-town young man with a lot of responsibility. Chief among his concerns are his mother (Darlene Cates), who is so overweight that she can't leave the house, and his mentally impaired younger brother, Arnie (Leonardo DiCaprio), who has a knack for finding trouble. Settled into a job at a grocery store and an ongoing affair with local woman Betty Carver (Mary Steenburgen), Gilbert finally has his life shaken up by the free-spirited Becky (Juliette Lewis).

reviews.content: This movie is such a sad movie, That's what makes a sad movie sad, they can change  your emotions throughout the movie, this is exactly what this movie did.
Such a Classic movie definitely very sad in some parts but all the actors did amazing!
Excellent acting and moving story.

An All Time Classic Film. The Acting by everyone is truly phenomenal especially Arnie & Gilbert. The cinematography is excellent capturing very fine detailed shots of everyone in the families reactions and also sweeping shots of the isolated lonely surrounding. The editing is very well done with just some minor loss of focus in the middle but with good reason. The Pacing is excellent with the film doing a fantastic job in the first 30 minutes allowing us to feel the weight that Gilbert carries and from there slowly feel the struggle to lift that burden and feel joy when we see it lifted over time. This is a truly sincere and heartfelt film that never crosses over into purposely pulling on the heartstrings to make up for a lack of substance but does because you love these characters and become invested in them. This is a film everyone should see once. An All Time Classic.

I loved this movie.  The acting was truly remarkable especially Leo DiCaprio's portrayal of Arnie.  I am not a huge movie buff but I found this movie left me thinking about it for a long time after viewing it.

This is a surprisingly touching film about a dysfunctional rural American family, with some pretty quirky characters and a number of now big name actors, including Johnny Depp as the titular character, Gilbert, and carer for the disabled brother, Arnie, played by Leonardo DiCaprio and John C. Reilly (of Stan & Ollie fame etc.), who plays 'Tucker Van Dyke' (a local).  I also recognised Mary Steenburgen, as Better Carver - she may be more well known as the mother in the short lived US show 'Zoey's Extraordinary Playlist'. 

At first this film seemed no more than ok but by the end, I thought it had become really rather poignant. Its a bit hard to review in depth, without giving away spoilers but I'd say its a good film in terms of depicting how difficult teenage carers may find things, when having to look after disabled siblings and parents. There is a sad side to it and there are some mildly amusing moments too. All in all, its a fairly thoughtful watch, one I'd recommend if your interested in the story or particularly keen on the cast then I'd say it's worth seeing, yes. I certainly can't say I've seen Leonardo DiCaprio in quite such a similar role before, certainly.

One of the best films I think I've ever seen, a classic, and the acting by Depp and Di Caprio was fantastic. I could watch this over and over and still not be tired of it. Tender, heartwarming, sad, endearing. You name it, it had all the qualities of an almost perfect film.
made me laugh and it made me cry. dicaprio portratied arnie so well
A simpler time, when Johnny Depp was a sweet soul devoted to family and Leonardo DiCaprio was content to climb water towards and hang out with his mama.

After watching several Johnny Depp films, and hearing of his personal life story during the trial, I see how Johnny has taken movie roles that allow him to process some of his own life experience through the character he is playing- as so beautifully displayed in his role as Gilbert in this movie.  Johnny has always stayed true to himself. Rejecting the ‘heart throb' image, he has diligently sought to be a respected actor who is true to himself.  Much respect.
Leonardo is phenomenal as well in this movie.
As are the other cast members.
Well done.
Simply an American classic with phenomenal acting. Also very well written — this is a must see for all audiences.
This movie is so touching. Great acting and story line and shows true hardship in a family
The movie has a lot of heart. And Johnny Depp and Leo had great screen chemistry.

I don't see what all the hype is about. Maybe it's just not my type of movie. But I also don't value family and the way most people do. I can appreciate the struggle of a young man trying to find a balance of living his life while being relied on to be a caregiver. Just not really movie material to me.

Love this movie! Fantastic acting, writing and storytelling. It's one of my favorite slice of life movies. It's a movie that everyone can relate to, whether you've been in Gilbert's (and the other characters') situation or not. 

Who would've thought going to a chain grocery store could be so impactful?

One of the best movies ever made. EYou can relate to each character and their genuine love for eachother despite the highly dysfunctional and volatile situation they are placed in. Fantastic acting by Johnny Depp, Leonardo DiCaprio, and even thheir sisters. The mother was amazing too

This slice of life story traces the everyday experiences and hurdles faced by a young man with an extremely unique family.

Just as Leo was the protagonist in Gangs of New York and was outshined by Day-Lewis in support, Depp had his leading role pushed to the side by DiCaprio, who gave the performance most will remember and one of the best of his career.

There are a handful of familiar faces in this but it seems I can't escape John C. Reilly lately, which is never a bad thing, having seen him in Gangs of New York, Winning Time, and now Gilber Grape, over the last two days.

I understand if people take issue with someone like a Leonardo DiCaprio taking a role like this to the lengths that he did but I felt he was authentic, respectful, and most importantly created the kind of tension and frustration that gives the audience a tiny glimpse of what circumstances can be like when a close family member suffers from an intellectual disability. 7.5/10

NYT 1000: #269
Johnny Depp + Di Caprio in a movie I was unaware of. Both already so good
Deeply sentimental, mundane yet touching, simultaneously uncomfortable and an ultimate comfort movie. Gilbert has my heart.
The brilliance of Depp and DiCaprio at early ages. This shows what a great script and great acting can do.
One of the greatest dysfunctional family dramas ever made.  Johnny Deep and Leonardo Dicaprio [in his most extraordinary role of all time] surviving homelife with a 500lb mom to pamper.

One of Depp's better movies. Great characterization and themes of loss of control, hope, desire. Independence and freedom in the face of inherited responsibilities. Letting go can be hard if the things you want to leave are just always there to take care of, it's jus what you have to do. But once you have the moment to let go, just let go, and go and don't get stuck in thinking too much. Just do what you want to do and go anywhere you want to go like the ending says.

Beautifully done movie. A thinker, not a stinker

One of Leonardo Dicaprio's best performances! Sure, he wasn't the best actor back in the 1990's, but this proves that he had the potential to really act. Every actor, along Johnny Depp, was great in this, making it one of the best dramas of the decade!

I went into this movie expecting it to be very boring, but it's a lot of fun. Johnny Depp is outstanding this complicated role. An even more outstanding performance is given by Leonardo Dicaprio.  It didn't know better I would have actually thought he is like that.  This movie is so heartfelt and heartbreaking that at some points the person you root for changes due to their actions. And another great thing about this film is actions have consequences which a lot of movies over look. I totally recommend this movie for any film fans looking for something to make them tear up and provide a story of love and pain.
Warm-hearted coming-of-age film with wonderful performances by DiCaprio, Depp and Lewis. One of the best movies of the 1990s.
Another great movie starring a diva!!!!

Summary: Trapped in a rural town, Gilbert's responsibilities are eating away at him. At the top of the list are caring for his obese, homebound mother and his dependent, younger brother with a mental disability. 

Takeaways: An unfortunate tale about a teenager living a stressful adult life. The build up of the small town gossip and demanding homelife are stressful for Gilbert and the viewer alike. Besides that, young Johnny Depp and Leonardo DiCaprio are fabulous.
Masterful acting performance with a slow-burn style. Literally coming-to-age slice-of-life literature work.

I liked it. It's a beautiful, artistic story.... soft and slow Americana. I was not blown away by Johnny Depp's acting nor all of the dialogue but was impressed with everything else and it is leagues ahead of the super hero films being turned out relentlessly  these days. Recommend!
Terrific film. Probably Johnny Depp's best performance and amazing acting from Leonardo DiCaprio as well. It's a very sad movie, but one definitely worth watching.
One of the best movies I've ever seen. Great plot - great cast. Leonardo and Johnny are doing a fantastic acting job in this film.
It's a good enough movie - not one you'll want to watch multiple times though.

This was a shockingly good movie. I didn't expect to like it as my mother recommended it to me and she rarely watches anything other than the Big Bang Theory but I thoroughly enjoyed this and would definitely recommend it to people.

I evidently haven't seen what many others have in this film. Maybe it's because I haven't grown up with this being considered a classic but I didn't find any aspect of the film particularly remarkable. It was very slow, the characters were bland, and the score was significantly underwhelming. The one interesting and standout factor as everyone else has pointed out is Leo DiCaprio's performance which may be one of the few of which he genuinely deserved to be in consideration for an Oscar. I don't really have any other thoughts on this film which in itself is an indictment of the experience.

Such an amazing story revolving around a young boy overwhelmed by his duties to his family and digested by his town. Apart from its power as a cinematic object, it is a fantastic nostalgia reminding us our towns and how they evolve through time with the emergence of supermarkets external to the town and the fast food restaurants which bring so-called modernity into the lives of the people. Stars of the movie were spectacular and it is wonderful to watch DiCaprio as a young actor who is just as good in his profession as his older version.
I can watch this film over and over again and I will never get tired of watching it.
What Eating Gilbert Grape is an instant coming of age classic. Johnny and Leo are amazing and have great chemistry

my husband and i watched it. played some fortnite inbetween and then watched the rest and it made his heart cry, he even "felt it in his nuts". Best movie so far. fuck you rules of attraction ur literally dog shit
Emotionally captivating, leonardo dicaprio predominated the film.

I have an autistic younger brother, leonardos acting was impecable. 

Good movie with good acting
You're just wrong honey

The movie ‘What's Eating Walter Grape' by Peter Hedges and Lasse Hallström was made in the year of 1993. The cast of the movie consisted of the famous Leonardo Dicaprio, Johnny Depp who are both abled bodied people. Specifically Lenardo who played Arnie played the character of a male who had autism while he himself didn't have autism. While watching I can say that none of the actions or portrayals of the character of Arnie was offensive and it seemed that the writers and producers had studied and educated themselves on the condition. When watching the movie it didn't have the character Arnie as comedic relief and instead it felt like the intentions of the movie were to give the reality of an autistic young adult in the 90's where they can be misunderstood and mistreated because of the limited education and support. Arnie is sometimes limited by his disability, when he wanted to go somewhere or do something he would get up and go do it. I think the one limitation would be taking care of himself with his hygiene and eating food, he would always have bath time which was done by the character of Gilbert. There was a scene in the movie where Gilbert is occupied with his new interest and the new girl so he tries to get Gilbert to understand that he is old enough to bathe himself since he is turning 18 in a few days. Once he feels that Arnie most likely could clean himself he rushes out and leaves Arnie. A whole night goes by and he assumes Arnie is in bed when he comes in late but when he goes to the bathroom he realizes Arnie had stayed the whole night in the tub and the water had turned super cold. After Gilbert apologizes profusely but it still happened which he regrets. There are many moments in the story where he is faced with apologizing to Gilbert for being inconsiderate and becoming understanding of Arnie as the show goes on. I wouldn't say that the character Arnie reached a feeling of empowerment but I think instead reached a feeling of acceptance from those around him. At the end of the story Arnie is able to find comfort in the same person that Gilbert finds growth in which is Becky. For example, at the beginning of the story Arnie wasn't as friendly to her and would shy away from her but by the end of the story when he had no one to turn to he instantly ran to Becky's trailer in asylum from Gilbert and his actions. When she leaves he says "bye friend" which is new for Arnie to regard someone who is not his family as a friend. With this growth from Arnie I think he grew a new sense of himself while also knowing he can do things for himself without Gilbert which I think is very touching. Coming from a, if this is ableist or not perspective I think that the goal of the movie was not to make fun of those who are autistic instead I think that the goal of the story was to provide the harsh reality and hardship that comes with being autistic in the normal world, especially in 1993. I think that it was successful of showing a deeper understanding of Arnie and his struggles while also showing his successes and how he got there with the help of himself, his family, and Becky.

Ableism in What's Eating Gilbert Grape

I chose to watch the film What's Eating Gilbert Grape (1993), a drama/romance about a boy growing up in a Midwestern town. The main character, Gilbert, is essentially his family's teen patriarch- having lost his father to suicide some years prior. His mother's morbid obesity renders her immobile, so he raises his younger siblings, Arnie, who has autism, and his sister. Gilbert's life is shaken up when Becky, a free-spirited traveller, arrives in town. Overall, I wouldn't say the whole movie is ableist, though it definitely falls into using some hackneyed and offensive tropes. 

One ableist theme stuck out to me is that Arnie is used somewhat as a plot device to further the character development of Gilbert. He brings Gilbert closer to his love interest, Becky, with his outgoing and friendly nature. At times, it seems as though Arnie is the ‘object' Gilbert and Becky bond over. On the other hand, the movie does have some good messaging around respect. In a critical scene in the film, Gilbert hits Arnie in frustration after he refuses to take a bath. Gilbert is tortured by guilt and their relationship is strained until Arnie retaliates by hitting him back in a playful, half-serious way. This act restores a sense of equality and mutual respect in the relationship and allows both characters to grow.
What's Eating Gilbert Grape provides a heartwarming and heartfelt story even though, it brings the viewers dread the whole film, it still has as satisfying ending
Timeless, emotional and real.

While the film was filled to the brim with cliches, with a incredibly simple and barebones story attached, it is very watchable. It feels like watching a good production of a Shakespeare play that you've seen a thousand times. The acting is really what pushes this one through.

Heart warming, simple story of a family's struggle to be normal while hiding and keeping to themselves. With a father that committed suicide, a son with mental health challenges and a wife and mother whom lost her way and self value in the aftermath of her husbands death, this story focuses from Johnny Depp's point of view and how he navigates his duties to his struggling family and his yearning for the possibilities of greater aspirations in life.
The acting in this film is superb. If you haven't seen Leonardo DiCaprio's early work.

Wholehearted to each & every coming-of-age story, there's a unity in Arnie's defiance & Gilbert's starry-eyed strive that makes for one big & surely special family. Like Becky's misty gaze, you're fixed from start to finish.
A bit predictable but overall very satisfying and enjoyable.

Hadn't expected to be impressed by this at all... Assumed it'd be cheesy, poorly acted, and sickeningly sentimental. However, this is a brilliant flick! The atmosphere is real, with the performances from Depp and DiCaprio nothing short of Oscar-worthy! The massive let down? Well, that'd be the story! Weak, fumbling, and aimlessly meandering, it lacks any real structure to hold up the other elements of this otherwise great film
Tell us a lot about love and family, simply meaningful movie. Hollywood needs to make movies like this one more. Absolutely a must watch.

So many and that's good because every family has problems. I wanted to see this movie years ago and finally I know what's eating Gilbert grape.

A timeless and unique drama about love, family and small town issues. Lasse Hallström's second best, after My Life As A Dog.
Johnny Depp and Leonardo Di Caprio did an amazing job in this movie, specially Di Caprio!
The performances are good but the story is a bit too melodramatic.

WHAT'S EATING GILBERT GRAPE is tender and heartwarming tale of dysfunction. Depp and DiCaprio's performances are both amazing, and the offbeat charm of the film is sure to captivate audiences everywhere.

This family drama within small town narrative was phenomenally performed all around from the brilliantly talented cast, amazingly led by Leonardo DiCaprio's breakthrough performance of hefty commitment and Johnny Depp's rare heartfelt performance of pure sincerity outside of his signature eccentricity. (A-)

I love the ending. It feels liberating.

a touching story about sibling love as well as family hardship. slow at points, but definitely was a moving film.

The 1993 film adapted from the Peter Hedges' novel, stars Johnny Depp as Gilbert Grape, a young man in small-town America tasked with caring for his obese mother and mentally impaired brother, Arnie, played by a young Leonardo DiCaprio. DiCaprio and Depp masterfully take on their roles to take the viewer inside this world of family, love, and small-town drama in a way that makes the viewer feel Gilbert's torment and Arnie's love of life. Where the acting was superb, the filmmaking by Lasse Hallström, was equally compelling. While the plot was predictable, the acting and filmmaking ensured this is a film you'll long remember.
Heartfelt drama with a brilliant performance from Johnny Depp and Leonardo DiCaprio
Absolutely classic movie!

I went with 3 1/2 stars for this movie, a throwback classic nostalgic movie I grew up watching. I have seen it many times but I have not seen it in a while, I would def. watch many more times to come. Great movie, actors, story heartwarming and tells the story of a family trying to live and survive. Go see this movie and give it some love 3 1/2 stars well worth the watch.
The star of di caprio so well done, minor story, great actors. Deep america
While DiCaprio gets most of the credit for his (very good) performance, Depp is criminally overlooked in a role that is less excessive but no less demanding. (3.5/5)

"What's Eating Gilbert Grape" effectively applies melodrama, romance, and comedy to tell a touching story that carefully depicts every day life in difficult family situations,  with Johnny Depp playing a very sweet and sympathetic character alongside Leonardo DiCaprio's Academy Award-nominated performance as his mentally challenged brother.

There are so many movies that have a strong emotional impact on me, but seldom that have ever brought tears to my eyes.  What's Eating Gilbert Grape is a rare and simple film that holds strong rewatchability due to its realistic atmosphere and heartwarming characters.
Both DeCaprio and Depp are massively talented men and have an overwhelmingly impressive lineup under their belt, but I don't know if any other work of theirs has quite reached what Gilbert Grape has.
Leo absolutely crushed this performance. It's a spectacular performance that could have been a total embarrassing farce. Arnie was real.

This is a film about a family with a lot of serious impediments.  Mum has outgrown her skeletal frame to the point that she can barely walk and her younger son has some kind of brain disorder that doctors thought would shorten his life dramatically.  The older one is still living at home trying to keep everything together along with the older sister while the younger sister is apparently also brain damaged (or maybe she's just 15).  The father died a good while ago and the house is falling apart as it was a DIY job apparently in a time where building codes didn't exist.  
Anyway, the film is rife with melancholly and interesting scenarios and heartfelt interplay between the characters.  Gilbert feels contempt for his mother, and it's explained some, and one gets the impression he's simply tired of the life he has and his mother simply personifies a good chunk at least of why he's tired of it.  One does get the impression that he could ease up and show pity instead of contempt but you also can imagine -- if you try --- the possibility that he's sick to his stomach of feeling pity for her and her mentally deficient son.  I can speak from experience that prolonged bouts of pity is extremely draining.  This guy's lived probably close to 20 years if not longer in this nothing horse town with his mostly broked -  out family.  Anyway, this film is extremely interesting while also arousing good size chunks of emotion.  It's probably one of my Top 10 favs.  It's defintiely one of the Top 100 movies, IMO.  I probably gravitate to it because my family is in some ways a little bit like that of Gilberts'.

A tender film that is difficult to watch at times, but for the right reasons. Leo as Arnie, the autistic boy on the cusp of his eighteenth birthday, gives such a stunning performance I remember not realizing it was him when I had first viewed the film back in high school. The rest of the Grape Family, headlined by Depp as the sensible patriarch, Gilbert, provides the viewer with a wonderful cast of characters — not to mention John C. Reilly, Crispin Glover, Juliette Lewis, and Mary Steenburgen in great supporting roles. But besides perhaps Arnie, the most recognizable character of the film is the morbidly obese Bonnie Grape (Darlene Cates), whose weight is often the topic of the small town's legend and lore. It is Bonnie's weight that leads us to the powerful ending, bringing so much of the plot full-circle. I've focused mainly on the characters because there really isn't all that much of a plot here, which I actually love — the characters' day-to-day lives drive the story through to the end, literally leaving us right where we started.
Excellent movie with a great cast! This is when great acting can carry a simple movie!

What’s Eating Gilbert Grape is a slice of life drama about a young man who clearly hates his life because he has to give all of himself to take care of his mother and brother. While he obviously loves them with his actions, you can tell he resents them because of how he talks about them. It’s a little difficult to watch at times because Johnny Depp, particularly at that age, was a thoroughly likable and charming guy. Yet in this film, he is put in a role where he is closed off emotionally and acts with a lot of frustration and anger. I suppose Depp works well enough for the role of Gilbert because he manages to make you sympathetic towards Gilbert rather than annoyed with him. The more noteworthy performance in What’s Eating Gilbert Grape is obviously from Leonardo DiCaprio. Fresh off his stint on Growing Pains, DiCaprio jumped into the deep end by taking on the role of a mentally-challenged teenager named Arnie. The best thing I can say about his performance is that it felt authentic, and I actually stopped seeing Leonardo and just saw Arnie. What’s Eating Gilbert Grape feels small to me, and didn’t impact me as powerfully as I would expect, particularly considering the subject matter. This is the kind of movie that could have easily made me bawl tears, and while I appreciate it not being overly saccharine, I wish I felt the emotions in a deeper way. I was almost to the point of boredom more than once while watching. I also struggled a lot with some of the subplots in the film. Juliette Lewis and the forced romance was not engaging to me at all. She’s not an actress I like all that much, and this character is the perfect fit for the label “manic pixie dream girl” which is rarely an interesting personality trait. Also, Mary Steenburgen simply doesn’t fit the mold of the desperate housewife role she is forced to play. I kind of hated her whole story and how it was an issue that quickly became a non-issue. When you set up and resolve things that fast and with that little consequence it feels like it never should have been included in the film. Needless to say, I had some issues with What’s Eating Gilbert Grape, but they weren’t enough for me to label it a “bad” film. It is just OK.
you should watch this movie because it's miracle

By far Depp best movie. Underrated movie about small town dysfunctional family trying to stay together. Unlike 95% of dysfunctional family movies doesn't have over top comedy to make it seem like everything is alright. Nor does it have over top drama forgetting that their is a middle ground for many people to relate to. Most our lives not that funny nor is that exciting. Gilbert Grape gives a real slice of life that our lives don't have to be like a movie to have meaning.
Beautiful, emotionally delightful; one of DiCaprio's best performances, if not the best
Words cannot describe how beautiful this movie is.  Leonardo DiCaprio's performance will stick in your head for a long time.
Emotional Journey. Well worth the watch

The movie is about a young man, whom is taking the place of his father. He dreams about getting out if the small town but he is a genuine soul that takes care of his family instead. The cast is enriched with talented actors. Love this movie.
it's emotioinal,heartfull,childness,with real family touch and is absolutely wonderfull.i recommend to watch this movie for all genre people

If you enjoy watching a realistic look at humanity...this is it...the characters and struggles are so real, so raw.... The acting is phenominal. I did not like it the first time that I saw it, but years later, after experiencing more in life, I watched it again with a greater understanding of reality, and I believe that this movie touches a nerve of reality that movies seldom do.

This is one of those movies that nothing ever really happens, and yet in the quiet, you can feel Gilbert's emotions all that much better.  Depp doesn't really do, say, or show emotion for most of this movie, but you can feel his teeth grinding.  The entire Grape family is there to annoy Gilbert (maybe not Amy for some reason).
This isn't really my type of movie, but as an adult, I can appreciate it more than I did when it came out.  Decent quirky character study.
PS: If you want to see machine guns and hackers, this is NOT your movie.
perfect cast, good performances and dialogue. a heart warming story

A touching piece of Americana.

Lasse Hallstrom's coming of age drama What's Eating Gilbert Grape (1993) is an enduring classic of Americana as it depicts small town living Iowa. Hallstrom shows the absolute degradation of a young man forced to take care of his mentally challenged brother, morbidly obese mother, desperate unhappy married girlfriend, all while working a dead end job in a quiet little town he despises. What's Eating Gilbert Grape feels so real as every character is like someone you know in real life. They are so ordinary country people. This film is a testament to the average American. It really is a shimmering example of rural America.

Peter Hedges' script is directly adapted from his novel of the same name. He creates a warm environment of brotherly love, empathetic understanding, economic stress, familial struggles, and familial love. His words all ring as if these characters might actually speak. The grounded realism of What's Eating Gilbert Grape enables it to persevere as a timeless film.

Hallstrom's direction allows for his actors to breath in an open scene full of life's little growing pains. His shots look so natural and sympathetic to his struggling characters. There is no judgement, only a realism that is deeply affecting. Sven Nykvist's cinematography harks back to his glory days as Ingmar Bergman's cinematographer. The outside wide shots make Iowa look serene, if desolate. Nykvist's cinematic look brings you to the heart of characters and their emotions indoors, while his shots look so profoundly ponderous outdoors. He captures a certain contemplative look in his close-ups and a sense of these people dreaming of something more than a small town life. Nykvist held dreams in his hands with his camera, while Hallstrom breathed life and compassion for unhappy people with his direction.

Alan Parker and Bjorn Isfalt's score is filled with mesmerizing piano melodies that soar across Hallstrom's skies and landscapes. The score to What's Eating Gilbert Grape creates an enchanting musical aura of tender affinity for these simple regular characters trying to get by in life.

Johnny Depp is phenomenal as Gilbert Grape. His eyes and face convey a deeper sadness and discontent with his life underneath his kindly actions. Depp portrays one of cinema's kindest heroes. His selfless actions and thoughts make you relate and care about Gilbert. Depp plays him so sincerely that Gilbert feels like you are watching a friend rather than a stranger.

Likewise, Leonardo DiCaprio is outstanding as the young brother to Gilbert Grape named Arnie Grape. DiCaprio portrays Arnie with a keen optimism and a debilitating mentally challenging condition. DiCaprio looks like he is having so much fun alongside Johnny Depp that you cannot help but like his character. DiCaprio delivers a convincing and an engaging performance despite his young age. DiCaprio was destined to be a great actor from the start.

Juliette Lewis gives one of her most likable and endearing roles as Gilbert Grape's girlfriend and Depp's love interest Becky. Her pixie haircut, energetic disposition, and sweet persona make Becky a delightful character to watch. She exhibits a dreamy quality that gives Becky an alluring mystique and blunt confidence. She is so fun and interesting opposite Depp as his love interest and foil. Their chemistry is apparent and believable. I completely fell for Lewis in What's Eating Gilbert Grape.

I must mention Darlene Cates as Gilbert's mother Bonnie Grape. Her brave portrayal of a woman suffering from morbid obesity is simultaneously revolting and heartbreaking. She makes you despise how lazy and not nurturing Bonnie is, then you sympathize with her once she's mocked and apologetic towards Gilbert. Cates' notable speech to Depp in her bed is so moving and captivating that Cates could never top this performance as What's Eating Gilbert Grape is sadly her only film role essentially. At least she is immortalized affectionately forever within What's Eating Gilbert Grape.

On the other hand, Mary Steenburgen is so hilarious as the naughty desperate housewife Betty Carver. Her performance is gripping as a miserably unhappy woman longing for Gilbert's love. Her forward flirtations and desperate attention seeking is entertaining as well as sorrow laden. Steenburgen is amazing in What's Eating Gilbert Grape.

Lastly, What's Eating Gilbert Grape features several perfect supporting roles. Laura Harrington is so nice and motherly as the Amy Grape, who must take care of the house since her mother will not. Mary Kate Schellhardt is so funny as the mean teenage sister Ellen Grape. Kevin Tighe is perfectly pathetic as the loser husband Ken Carver, who has been cuckolded by Gilbert Grape sleeping with his wife Betty. Crispin Glover is creepy and hilarious as the good humored mortician friend to Gilbert named Bobby McBurney. Finally, John C. Reilly is so nice as the handy electrician and contractor friend to Gilbert named Tucker Van Dyke. These actors and actresses all contribute to What's Eating Gilbert Grape's realistic vibe.

In all, What's Eating Gilbert Grape is a triumph of beautiful direction and tender sentiment with excellent acting set to lovely music.
A fav.  So well done.  Beautiful story and relationships.
A favorite childhood movie of mine.

Whats eating Gilbert Grape is one of those little treasures that for the most part most people do know about,mainly due to Leonardo Dicrapio knock out performance as Arnie Grape. I did not hate the movie don't mind the number rating, I liked it, its just to long for me and some parts are cheesy, but I like the visuals and its makes us feel like we're seeing life in a different way than usual. So for this being a decent movie with actors that will become one of the best actors in their time, I give " Whats Eating Gilbert Grape " a D.

A fantastic film that will cause you to weep every time due to fantastic writing and a stellar performance from Leonardo DiCaprio. "What's Eating Gilbert Grape" is definitely worth a watch, and probably one of the greatest dramas of all time.

Great amazing phenomenal movie starring Johnny depp and Leonardo DiCaprio. This movie is amazing and the chemistry between Leonardo and Johnny is amazing. Leonardo is very young in this and how does he do it, he's good as a kid and an adult. This movie felt like a real family and boy does this particular family have problems. So many and that's good because every family has problems. I wanted to see this movie years ago and finally I know what's eating Gilbert grape.
I loved it. I don't find anything wing with the movie. Johnny Depp and Leonardo Decaprio were both amazing at there roles and one of my new favorite

This has always been one of my favorite movies, such a great cast. The writing is also very good, heartwarming family story. Everyone should see this film, we all long to get away sometimes like Gilbert did.

Every once in a while, one watches a movie that has no major plot twists, or a grand story. The movie makes no pretensions of being a "path-breaking" or melodramatic film. Its a simple story of a family, with 4 children and their mother. 15 minutes into the movie your are empathising with Gilbert Grape, the son who has to take care of his autistic brother and earn money to run the house. You are hoping there will be some redemption where he suddenly makes a lot of money or lands a great job or something else heroic. But it never happens. The story progresses through routine daily events and yet leaves a profoud impact at the end of the movie. Gilbert Grape has his weak moments but is the epitome of dealing with adversity with grace. Which is another way of saying that he has courage, of loving, caring, and losing. Wonderful movie.

Leonardo DiCaprio's true breakout performance and one of Johnny Depp's most empathetic make What's Eating Gilbert Grape stand the test of time as one of the most prominent drama's ever to hit the big screen. It's very important you watch.

What's Eating Gilbert Grape is a touching movie, and even with its predictable end, it has a top notch cast, it is interesting and I have to say that I loved the way they established the ties between the characters.
As real as it gets. The characters are so well played in this film and you can’t help but to feel the intensity, pain, and joy along side them.

The best aspect of this movie is acting. It conveys more of a message than the cinematography, even though the cinematography is really good. It's an emotional rollercoaster. Leonardo really gave his best in this movie and there's no doubt about that.
I'm boycotting all Johnny Depp's works nowadays except this one. It's too good to not watch again and again
Leo's talent is on full display in the quirky, off-beat film. Honestly, I like it, but I found it hard to get through on more than one occasion.
moving story in addition to an amazing performance by leonardo dicaprio

I do normally enjoy Lasse Hallstrom's quirky movies but I find What's Eating Gilbert Grape? to be a rather tedious, lacklustre affair. Despite a strong cast, headed by Johnny Depp, I just find it all a bit pointless and disengaging. The whole of the Grape family really need to be shaken by the shoulders until they get a grip and actually do something. What we have is a couple of hours in the company of a hugely dysfunctional family and I felt as trapped as Gilbert himself. Thank heavens for the common sense, spark and levity provided by Juliette Lewis as the holidaymaker who comes into Gilbert's life and makes him see some of the wonder in life. Her character, Becky, really does save the day and stop this from being a totally depressing and downbeat trial to watch.

A warm movie even though things that are depicted in it are absolutely not that warm. But the feelings and emotions are so genuine and honest that you feel connected with this family and its problems. Acting is perfect especially, of course, the young Di Caprio and Johnny Depp. I'm not even sure how Di Caprio was preparing for this role, he lived it. Johnny Depp took the reverse role of his another film of this year 'Benny & Joon' playing the brother who has to take care of his mentally ill younger sibling. But this time the whole family depends on him. You genuinely care for all of them and wish them luck. Sometimes it's more than enough for a movie to be really good.

What's Eating Gilbert Grape is a spectacular warm hearted film showing some people's struggles in life. All of the performances are very moving, especially Leonardo Dicaprio who's the one that will take your breath away. He does a truly outstanding job playing a teen with mental illness that shows the audience what mental illness is like. This warm hearted coming of age film is something all audiences can enjoy while feeling sadness and joy throughout,
Can't wait for the redo when the fix the ending...spoiler alert....burn down the house...really?

An enjoyable movie with a bunch of young folks who turned into stars (Johnny Depp, Leo DiCaprio, Juliette Lewis, John C Riley, and Crispin Glover). 

DiCaprio's (who is nearly unrecognizable because of how young he is) performance was really good.

Overall a good, interesting movie.

I'll argue with anyone who disagrees that this film has Leonardo DiCaprio's greatest ever performance. What's Eating Gilbert Grape is a refreshingly original film about the challenges that come with a dysfunctional family life. What's Eating Gilbert Grape is remembered for its performances; notably from young DiCaprio, whose portrayal of Arnie is just incredible. The film struggles in remaining completely coherent. Focuses on lots of little subplots instead of a few powerful ones. Weak supporting roles don't undermine What's Eating Gilbert Grape. A really interesting film from a director who hasn't quite met this standard since.
A non insane Crispin Glover is the icing on this one of a kind movie!

Based on the novel of the same name by Peter Hedges. Gilbert Grape lives in Endora, a place where nothing much happens. Gilbert is his family's main breadwinner and also has to care for his mentally disabled brother Arnie (DiCaprio) and his morbidly obese mother, which becomes a challenge when love walks into his life. Leonardo DiCaprio in one of his best roles. Great film!

A real heartwarming film, especially one that most people who cling to each other forever can relate to. The relationship between Gilbert and Arnie is somewhat difficult to explain, but it translates so great on screen. You realize the brotherhood through thick and thin and recognize the patience Gilbert has, the struggles he faces, and the hope for a new life. The characters and setting seem like something out of time in a modern era, yet the way it conveys life there is genuine if not totally realistic. There are laughs and there are tears, and Lasse Hallström gives us the glimpse in a way we end up somehow seeing ourselves. Add some moving performances from  Johnny Depp and Leonardo Dicaprio in the center and it leaps forward with wonder. So if anyone asks what's eating you, whatever it is, maybe it's also what's eating Gilbert Grape, too.

Having a Johnny Depp-a-thon. Never heard of this film, just saw it for the first time. Was surprised to see Johnny Depp& Leonardo DiCaprio together. Even more surprised to see Leo as a mentally disabled teen. The film was good, brought me back to the good old days of film when stories were original and not franchise remakes or comic books
Perhaps a bit too melancholy, but What's Eating Gilbert Grape is an okay film, with Johnny Depp and Leonardo DiCaprio giving their all.

"What's Eating Glibert Grape" was a movie that I had been curious about after always seeing it in my "recommended movies" on Netflix. This movie was nothing like what I expected but I was impressed with the unusual family situation that was brought to light. Gilbert seems to be carrying the weight of the family after his father passed away. While the son stepping up to be the man of the house is not unusual when the father is no longer in the picture, the responsibility of taking care of his mentally disabled brother and morbidly obese mother was a challenge I had never seen presented in a movie before. The movie was filled with the tough times that try a family after the loss of a parent but also hope for new beginnings. Gilbert's view of Endora was grim in the beginning of the movie and there seemed to be nothing there for him except for his brother Arnie. When Becky came into town in an RV Gilbert began a transformation and when his heart opened up to Becky, it also opened back up to his family.
Just watched this with my wife's son and it was fantastic! Now we know whats eating Gilbert Grape 10/10
Leo and Depp work magic with each other in this classic
I had forgotten what a wonderful movie this is.  Leonardo DeCaprio and Johnny Depp were so great together.  Watching it again reminds me of Mom.  She sure liked this one.

I don't know what I was supposed to take away from this movie.  Life sucks less when your mom dies and you don't have to take care of your family anymore and can have sex with someone your own age? I dunno if this suffered from being edited for TV, but there just seemed to be a whole lot of no point. The acting was good enough, I'm not a fan of Depp or DiCaprio at all but they delivered acceptable performances. I like Mary Steenbergen. But all in all this movie got a big "So what?" out of me.
Amazing acting by Leonardo Di Caprio as Arnie Grape.

Uncanny drama about a young man named Gilbert from a small Midwestern town whose life with his reclusive overweight mother and his mentally ill brother make him think about leaving them for something better, that is until he meets an attractive visitor who helps Gilbert through his emotional baggage. This sleeper hit is now regarded as a classic, but at the time of its release, it was viewed as a humorous inside look at a troubled family.

Two words... Leonardo DiCaprio. Thats really all you need when it comes to experiencing this movie. DiCaprio will always be the highlight of this film and you should't be surprised why that is. But waiting on the other end is the outstanding performance from Johnny Depp. Hallstrom's direction is great as well, but yes, Leo is your reason for enjoying this.

Wow, I've written and lost this review 3 times now. Frustrating...

So, trying again!

This was directed by Lasse Hallstrom, which helps explain why I like it so much. He brings an optimism and compassion to his work.

This is set in a pairie town pre-cell phone era, featuring a struggling family. The family is held together by the will of the mother, an extremely obese shut in played by Darlene Cates. The father is long gone, and it was his leaving that drove her to eat and stay shut in. Two of her children do everything to care for the family, Gilbert played by Johnny Depp and Amy played by Laura Harrington. Gilbert especially takes a lot of responsiblity on his shoulders, between working bagging groceries to support the family and  taking responsibility for the care of his developmentally disabled brother Arnie, played by a young Leonardo DiCaprio.

All of this responsibility is made lighter for Gilbert by his summer romance with a girl about his age, Becky played by Juliette Lewis. In order to focus on Becky, Gilbert has to shrug off the older married woman he is having an affair with (played by Mary Steenburgen). It's complicated and messy.

A situation with brother Arnie escalates and Momma finds it in herself to leave the house for the first time in YEARS to go help her son. Following this triumph, she attempts to make some changes with the help of Gilbert and Amy, but sadly her health has reached its limit. 
 

What's Eating Gilbert Grape shows us love, family unity, struggle, loss, success, and survival. Most people can find something to identify with, something familiar here. Although this family may look different from most of ours. Few, if any, other directors have taken on the family dynamics involved with extreme obesity, and I doubt any have done it better than Lasse Hallstrom.
Dicaprio is so convincing if you didn't know otherwise you would assume he was mentally handicapped. Fantastic film.
In the middle of the Depp-Heard war. I wanted to watch this again for the Nth time and this time cried buckets than before.

'What's Eating Gilbert Grape' is perhaps one of the best dramas of the 1990s, next to Forrest Gump and several others. Johnny Depp is great as Gilbert, and Leonardo Dicaprio is fairly convincing as his mentally handicapped brother, Arnie. Such an incredibly moving film.

This coming-of-age movie stars Johnny Depp in the titular role, and he does fantastic work. However, the real story here is the performance given by Leonardo DiCaprio. Playing a young adult with mental illness, DiCaprio managed to pull off a wonderful performance without being offensive or watered-down. The subtle music really fit in well with the small-town feel. There were a few conveniences in the storyline, namely with the Carver family, but it didn't take away from the effect of the film overall. As far as feel-good movies go, this is one of the better examples; a bittersweet happy ending can have a lasting touch, and What's Eating Gilbert Grape has clearly impacted viewers to have such a following today.

What's Eating Gilbert Grape is a heartbreaking, heartfelt American Classic. With beautiful performances, expert cinematography, and a very brilliant script the film succeeds in way more ways than one. It is definitely the highlight of DiCaprio's career, as he gives an unbelievable Oscar-worthy performance. Even if it is tough to watch, it is sweetly uplifting.

Leonardo DiCaprio and Johnny Depp portray very believable characters in this film. This is a one-of-a-kind movie, which makes it so unique compared to other films out there. I wouldn't give this a five, however, due to a weak plot. The movie is centered around a relationship between a special 17-year-old boy and his older, overworked brother. The conflict revolves around Gilbert Grape's (Johnny Depp) troubles in his life, such as dealing with his younger, mentally impaired brother Arnie, taking care of his obese mother, and juggling an affair with a married woman. The movie emphasizes this a little too much, resulting in exposition buildup.
Leo is one of the best actors if not the best actor alive.

Absolute outstanding acting. Johnny Depp once again seems to change his whole appearance for this film. Emotion was easily processed. Leonardo Dicaprio had me confused thinking it was someone playing the role of Arnie. I believed it was a real mentally disabled actor. Great Performance.

The chemistry that Depp and DiCaprio have is amazing and so is the movie. Depp is magnificent and DiCaprio plays a roll that few would have the capacity to do as an adult let alone as an 18 year old.  

There's little to complain about here. The movie is a gem.
Gilbert Grape does not get eaten by anything in this movie. very misleading.

Honestly, one of the best movies I've ever seen. Leo's performance is absolutely unbelievable. To think some people actually thought Leo was actually mentally handicapped truly proves how great he was.

What's Eating Gilbert Grape is an excellent film. It is Gilbert who has to care for his mentally disabled brother, Arnie, and his morbidly obese mother after his father died. Johnny Depp and Leonardo DiCaprio give fantastic performances. The screenplay is well written. Lasse Hallestrom did a great job directing this movie. I enjoyed watching this motion picture because of the drama and romance. What's Eating Gilbert Grape is a must see.

It's hard to believe that Leonardo DiCaprio has still not won an Oscar to this day.  His performance in this at just twenty years old is superb.  Sadly, his history of Oscar subs started here.  Superb.

Engaging and original even years later, with some great performances from some talented actors. The oddball characters with their boring lives somehow manage to raise the mundane into the extraordinary and the plot is not at all predictable (i.e., not a Hollywood ending). I realize this sounds like a generic review of a movie I (really really) like, but it's about What's Eating Gilbert Grape.

Excellent film; the most notable actors have to be Johnny Depp and Leonardo. With that being said: it takes much appreciation to understand the power of Leo's performance and the transformation/creation of Johnny Depp's suave style. Overall a sentimental and heartwarming movie, it thoroughly explains the entailment of heart into manhood.

Excellent film; the most notable actors have to be Johnny Depp and Leonardo. With that being said: it takes much appreciation to understand the power of Leo's performance and the transformation/creation of Johnny Depp's suave style. Overall a sentimental and heartwarming movie, it thoroughly explains the entailment of heart into manhood.

Gilbert Grape, the main character, the hero of this small town.  the entire movie is centered around his change. Well nothing changed.  The title Who Ate Gilbert Grape leads you to believe that someone or something is going to cause him to change his life for the better.  At best he changes his outlook on caring for his beloved brother Artie who he feels that no one should ever harm no matter what the reason.  However, in reality nothing changes. He still lives and works in no-name town Iowa caring for his dysfunctional family hoping to find true love and a true purpose.Leonardo Di caprio's character  Artie Grape is a 17 year old special needs kid who is turning 18.  He won an oscar for his role and I commend him for pulling  off such a difficult role. It may have been the best part of the entire film.  Unlike his colleagues he played the only static character and did so beautifully. Artie at the beginning of the movie was the same Artie that was at the end of the movie. Unlike the rest of the players he is supposed to remain static.  
Becky, played by Juliette Lewis is the fair maiden that Gilbert Grape falls in love with (perhaps the character who changes the most).  Becky and her grandmother are stranded in their small town in Iowa after their car breaks down. As the story goes, she gives Gilbert a new way of thinking of life and gives him hope of a brighter future. However, any change she causes is subtle at best. Despite being their to talk with Gilbert all night after one of the most intense scenes of the film, Becky only gets him to elevate his level of responsibility of caring for his brother artie and supporting the rest of his family.  She develops an intent to change in Gilbert and finds her self falling in love with our story's main character.
Gilbert's two sisters also have an important role to play if Gilbert Grape is to rise and be the protagonist promoted of by the film.  While the director shows the role they play as being the other half of supporting the dysfunctional Grape household, they needed change in their character. As the movie progressed they should have grown to be more supportive of gilbert's dreams and desires to move out of their town and search after a greater purpose.  Instead, the two sisters Amy and Ellen (played by Laura Harrington and Mary Kate Schellhardt) play a static antagonist that demoralize gilbert's ambitions and encourage that fact that he is stuck in Iowa caring for their brother artie and caring for other needs of their dysfunctional family.
Perhaps the most decayed part of their family is not the lack of a father but rather the lack of a caring mother.  While glimpses of a true "mama bear" were present Darlene Cates Character, Bonnie Grape proved to be a thorn in the side of the struggling family.  She provided 
The Characters in Who Ate Gilbert Grape don't evolve throughout the movie. They remain static.  I would not recommend watching this movie
Wow, very poignant. What a tear jerker!
LOVE LOVE LOVE this movie

I've watched this movie many times, and I am always drawn in by the incredible portrayal of the different characters, each of their individual motives and passions and fears and stories. I love the idea that we get to follow Gilbert through an escalation of various obstacles and conflicts, some conflicts bleeding into others, and how all the characters around him are right on his level. Gilbert and his story and journey is no more important and no less important than that of those around him. Something brings me into the overall tone of this story and I can just easily follow along and live the life of Gilbert and his family, and when the movie is over I continue to think in this mindset long after, as if it truly touched me. It's just a beautiful movie to me. I am inspired by the acting, the detailed character traits, flaws, and histories, and the seamless trudging through a tiny story in a tiny town.

I can relate to this story, because I'm autistic myself! You can feel Gilbert's trials and tribulations as he tries to support his family. It's such a heavy burden, but the portrayal here, and the acting, it is just priceless! Definitely not only one of the best dramas of all time, but one of the best films of all time, period!

What's Eating Gilbert Grape is a film that lovingly focuses on the complexities of small-town life.  Read my full review at movie-op.blogspot.com.

Lovely, heartbreaking, but sometimes flawed, this may not be the best drama despite it's steady hand on touchy subjects, but it does stand as an enthralling against-type example for each of its cast members.
Interesting and mysterious.

This was a touching and very troublesome film. With Johnny Depp as Gilbert Grape he captured the part of a lonely farm boy perfectly. Also Leonardo has proven his acting skills by playing Arnie, the retarded brother. Their couldnt be a more inspiring, yet realistic plot and ending to this movie.

A surprisingly effective film. Leonardo DiCaprio was unknown to me when this film came out in 1993. He is so convincing I actually thought he was a mentally challenged actor. The film is a must see for his work alone.

I spend a lot of this film amused by how much the actor playing Arnie reminded me of Leonardo DiCaprio. I was shocked when I saw that it was him. I never thought that he was capable of such a role and an amazing performance. This was the highlight of the film, the rest was a bit dull. Juliette Lewis was the completely wrong choice for the role of Becky, I thought.

"What's Eating Gilbert Grape's" odd atmosphere contributes to its unique sentimentality and moving story. The performances are fantastic. Johnny Depp is great here and so is Juliette Lewis, but the performance that comes off scarily real is that of the early Leonardo DiCaprio. He was nominated for an Oscar for his portrayal of the mentally handicapped Arnie, and it's very easy to see why.

With Johnny Depp's overlooking narration, we're given the immediate sense of the family-man caretaker that defines his character. This is also the movie that MADE Leonardo DiCaprio, so we have to be thankful for that.

It flawlessly captures the small town essence and the problems that plague plenty of families. While Depp puts in a wonderfully measured and level-headed performance, the star of the show is a young DiCaprio.

"I want Momma to take aerobics classes. I want Ellen to grow up. I want a new brain for Arnie. I want..."

Looking back at Leonardo DiCaprio's filmography I'm constantly reminded what a great actor he is. In What's Eating Gilbert Grape, he plays a seventeen year old mentally ill kid in such a natural way that if I didn't know this was Leo I would've believed the actor playing Arnie was really mentally ill. This is probably one of his standout performances and is one of the highlights of this emotionally gripping family drama. However he is just a supporting character in this film as the title character is played by Johnny Depp, Arnie's older brother who is always taking care of him and the rest of the family. Gilbert's father has abandoned them and ever since he has been the male role model for the family in the small community where they live. He not only takes care of Arnie, he also has to provide for the family by working in a small local supermarket. He is ashamed of his obese mother (Darlene Cates), who simply stopped caring about her beautiful body after her husband abandoned her. Gilbert also has two sisters who help out with the family chores, Amy (Laura Harrington) and Ellen (Mary Kate Schellhardt). The responsibility Gilbert feels towards his family has taken its toll on him and explains why he seems to be half asleep all the time. He has no time for accomplishing any personal goals or dreams and spends his few free minutes with his local friends, Tucker (John C. Reilly) and Bobby (Crispin Glover). Things take an unexpected turn when Becky (Juliette Lewis) arrives in town and the two form a special bond together. What's Eating Gilbert Grape is an emotionally gripping family drama that works thanks to the strong performances from the cast and a fantastically well written script by Peter Hedges. The film avoids feeling cliche or melodramatic and I found it to be an honest story. Lasse Hallstrom has been accused of being overly melodramatic at times, but I think that the director avoided much of those moments here thanks in most part to a well written script.

Leonardo DiCaprio gives the best performance of the film, but Johnny Depp also delivers in a very subtle way. His character doesn't seem to say much, but the way he simply moves and speaks says a lot about him. He knows he isn't getting anywhere in life and feels stuck in this small town, but at the same time he has responsibilities and knows that his family relies on him to survive. He is trapped in a prison he can't get out of. He cares deeply for his family, but at the same time he resents them and it seems they have become a burden for him. The way he approaches the character is fascinating because he doesn't have to say or do anything for us to understand how he feels. We can easily identify and sympathize for his character. The chemistry he shares with Lewis is also strong. She is in some ways the opposite of him. She is free spirited and has travelled across several states. She doesn't have many responsibilities, and the two end up complementing each other quite well. Their relationship might not be the central theme of the movie, but it does lighten up the mood a bit. Reilly is always funny on screen and despite playing a more serious character he still delivers his usual quirky silliness to the role. All these small relationships are the central theme of the movie and the brotherhood between Depp and DiCaprio stands out above them all. I enjoyed this family drama and I'm glad I finally got a chance to watch it.

finally saw it after several unsuccessful attempts. was not disappointed. Leonardo di Caprio is amazing. Juliette Lewis is exceptionally looking. The story is well written and the direction is good. worth your time.

A slice of life film about a small town family struggling to make it years after a family tragedy (the suicide of Gilbert Grape's father).  Gilbert is played by Johnny Depp in his (in my opinion) best performance of his career.  Depp was reportedly struggling with personal issues of his own during filming, and he certainly seems to use that despair in his performance.  A tremendous cast, including a then unknown John C. Reilly, a young and incredible Leonardo DiCaprio, Juliette Lewis, and many relatively unknown others who give this movie tremendous depth.  Everywhere you look there are talented actors adding color to this movie and almost every scene is affecting.  It's a toss up between DiCaprio's performance as a boy with special needs, and Darlene Cates, a morbidly obese woman who had never acted before in her life for finest performance in this movie.  Depp is excellent, but DiCaprio is a revelation and Cates is painfully honest and brave.  This movie feels more like what real-life feels like than most Hollywood films have achieved.  There are funny moments, tender moments and sad, lonely and desperate moments.  Life can be very hard, with responsibilities and relationships to manage, and this movie captures that struggle and makes it compelling.  Despite mostly positive reviews, this film remains underrated and is quickly becoming a forgotten masterpiece.

What's Eating Gilbert Grape is a terrific movie that created a new star that is Leonardo DiCaprio. Johnny Depp is really great and it's really nice to see him in drama movies. Leonardo DiCaprio is absolutely amazing and it's great to know that he got nominated for an Oscar, especially when he was a kid at the time. The supporting cast are great, it's interesting to watch, and the chemistry between Gilbert and Arnie is really good. Peter Hedges did a great job adapting his own book into a movie  and knows what dialed kids are like with some great directing by Lasse Hallstrom. Only problem I had is that it's predictable at times, but the story also has some surprising moments too. What's Eating Gilbert Grape is a great drama that has done effectively well.

DiCaprio gave a solid performance, and the atmosphere was nailed. However, everything else was just aggressively serviceable. Depp was kind of wooden. 
Verdict: C+

Simple films about small-town life are not always enjoyable. That being said, 'What's Eating Gilbert Grape?' is one of the rare successes out of this mold. It is my favorite Leonardo DiCaprio role to date.

The story is indeed tight and sentimental. But the true brilliance of the film is Leo's performance. How he has not won an Oscar yet, is beyond me. What's Eating Gilbert Grape is an endearing story about an Middle America family; one you should watch for Leo's performance if nothing else.
The two performances at the heart of this movie are brilliant in their own specific way while the plot doesn't quite have the knockout quality it could. Full review later.
A truly touching and unforgettable film due to Depp's and DiCaprio's sincere performances.
What a piece of work. It's so real with the actors bringing the story to life. Di Caprio at his best.
A good movie if you want to feel very sad all the time also that's actually Leonardo Dicaprio and not just some kid later in his career he will do cocaine off of strippers in a 3hr Scorsese film
Hands down Leonardo's best work. Johnny depp was great in this film but leo was just amazingly perfect in this film. This was a oscar worthy performances. The film was good and so was the story.

I was expecting a middlebrow drama. I was pleasantly surprised with an offbeat heart-tugger more in line with great work by filmmakers like Emir Kusturica, Jean-Jacques Beineix, and Leos Carax. Really loved it.

A real story about life with a handicapped family member back before it was acceptable. Gilbert Grape is trying to hold his family together and live a normal life while bending drastically under the stress of caring for a brother in need of constant attention, caring for a sister who has built a shell around herself, and protecting his mother from the outside world after the world proved too much for her. But the question stands through all of it, what is eating away at Gilbert Grape? Well worth the 117 minutes.
One of my favorite movies, ever.
One of my favorite movies. Leonardo DiCaprio's performance drew me in to care about Arnie, the sweet little guy. His acting was very realistic and made me emotional. Where is his Oscar, America?
One of those forgotten gems from the 90's, can't express my passion for this film enough, it's so unique in every aspect and the characters are relatable.

What's Eating Gilbert Grape is one of those movies that really makes you think. Johnny Depp's portrayal of Gilbert really made you think of who and what you want to be. Depp and Dicaprio really were standouts in this movie but the other characters besides Becky were not given enough background about. The beginning of the movie we are introduced to the other characters but that's pretty much all we learn about them. I would've liked to learn more about their family and especially more about their brother that doesn't live their anymore. The whole story itself was very interesting and fun. Though it was depressing at times it had a lot of heartfelt moments. Any moment between Becky and Gilbert or Arnie and Gilbert was really special and sweet. There's really no way you can't enjoy those moments. I really liked John C Reilly in this movie too. His character was generally really nice and helpful and just always made me happy to see him acting. I also really enjoyed seeing the changes that Gilbert goes through. He's constantly kinda in a eh mood but he's happy at times, sad, really mad, and caring. He has almost unlimited patience. The thing I didn't like about this movie is the whole Gilbert making deliveries to that one lady's house. That character got irritating after a while and I didn't care for scenes with her in it. I was pleased when she left the movie. I really liked the ending. It ended on a total bittersweet note which was expected but what wasn't expected was the (spoiler!) death of an unexpected character! I was shocked actually! Through great storytelling but some eh scenes What's Eating Gilbert Grape has a great story, great performances, and a great ending. B+

A tender drama about Gilbert (Johnny Depp) whose responsibilities towards his obese mother and mentally handicapped brother creates restrictions on his own life. Definitely provides a clear picture of how strenuous caring for physical or mentally handicapped individuals can be but arguably the clearest message this movie conveys is how Leonardo DiCaprio's remarkable acting ability flourished at such a young age. Great performance which invited an Academy Award nomination but should he have won? Out of all of DiCaprio's performances I've seen so far, I think this role was the one where the Oscar eluded him most wrongfully.

Leonardo Di Caprio portrays one of his greatest performances as an autistic boy in this "What's eating Gilbert's grape?" that is very much deserving of his oscar nomination that he has recieved. Reflecting this movie portrays certain lifestyle issues in a very depth, well thought and honest way. Living with an autistic person is very much so the same as its shown in the movie and the director should be applaused by portraying these aspects in such an honest and sincere manner. in general the whole film is very sincere. The only ledge between the wheel for me is that it wasnt supported by such a good script. i thought that it looked almost like the actors were reading of the script and didnt learn them. Discrete performances by the actors and discrete story. Another thing is why was it important to have an affair between a mid-wife and the lead actor. Apart from that it was an enjoyable film to see.
One of my favorite movies!  Love it.
An underrated performance from Leonardo Di Caprio

Ever so often a gem such as "What's Eating Gilbert Grape" comes along and allows us the privilege to experience what cinema is capable of.  The story is tangible, the characters loveable and the comedy laughable.  Leonardo Dicaprio is beyond spectacular and Johnny Depp is Johnny Depp.  I wonder how this flew under my radar for so many years.
Leonardo DiCaprio should've got an Oscar for this movie.  But other than his acting it was kinda weird and stupid...

a lovable, charming, and emotional tale.

Score: This movie is BADASS
pretty slow, but Leo's performance was great. why is his character always so dirty all the time - does he just eat dirt all day?

I really didn't enjoy the film as much as I wanted to, but there was a lot that was done well. It shows some very real life situations about dysfunctional families that can get so wound up in chaos that there is little they can do about their situation. Gilbert Grape makes some interesting societal remarks, but doesn't quite hit home as much as it should
Great debut movie by Leonardo Dicaprio he acted amazing and no wonder he became such a big actor after this!

Gilbert Grape is a responsible young man whose life is overwhelmed by all of those around him. From his mentally handicapped brother to his overweight mother we soon learn what's eating Gilbert Grape.
I feel like Why was I so late watching this movie?? What's so great about the movie is it's simplicity and  innocence ...  Simply Amazing :)

A drama with a lot of heart. Lasse Hallström directs this beautiful story of a guy (Johnny Depp) who has to take care of his mentally handicapped younger brother (Leonardo DiCaprio). This story is one of the few that really reach into my heart and pull a few strings. I also think this is Leonardo DiCaprio's BEST performance, he should have won the Oscar that year (but for some reason Tommy Lee Jones won it). This is a beautiful movie that I highly recommend.
a great movie story and acting

The film accurately captures the feeling of small town, Middle America, and soars on its emotional story. DiCaprio is absolutely brilliant in his performance. If for nothing else, watch What's Eating Gilbert Grape for him. Ultimately, the film left me with a smile, a credit to how the director was able to draw us in and care about the characters.

An endearing portrayal of the struggle of a mentally disabled boy in a world that lacks understanding. Though the film focuses on that boy's brother, it is just as much about him. Leonardo DiCaprio's performance was an early sign of the brilliant actor that he would become.
Leo DiCaprio has bursted onto the scene and put veteran actors in their place. Otherwise, a sentimental, understated tragedy that can be tear-jerking, and at the same time, fun to watch.
It is nice to see retarded DiCaprio.

A very compelling film that wrestles with what it means to be loving and faithful, dealing with change, and overcoming shame. DiCaprio is fantastic in his role as a mentally challenged teen brother to Depp who helps highlight the challenges and joys of everyday life.
one of the most amazing films that I have ever seen.
It was ok... I watched this after the Titanic so it was hard to believe that it was Leonardo DiCaprio playing Arnie. It definitely showed his talents to the world

I've heard for years that this was a must-see movie with genius performances by a very young DiCaprio and coming-to-maturing Depp.

Those reviews were correct. Stunning.
One of the best performances by the actors in terms of acting.

Whats Eating Gilbert Grape is the story of a young man named Gilbert (Johnny Depp) who feels like he is stuck in his life. He has to constantly take care and stand up for of his brother Arnie (Leonardo DiCaprio) who has a disability. He is ashamed of the rest of his family, including his mother. The film is about Gilbert and his life of sameness, until a special girl comes into his life. This film is touching, well acted, and well filmed. 4.7 stars!
Leo was robbed should have got an Oscar great movie
